results.title: Shringar: hair styles of India
results.creator_credit: Films Division, Government of India, Ezra Mir and Ravi Prakash
results.brief_description: Indian women’s hair styles; their origin in tradition; how the hair is dressed and how the styles may be adapted to wear with Western dress. A stylist makes sketches for hair styles based on those seen in temple carvings and the Ajunta cave frescoes; how the hair is oiled and the styles built up; the use of garlands, particularly jasmine, and jkewellery; dressing a Western woman’s hair in adaptations of Indian styles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Films Division, Government of India, Ezra Mir and Ravi Prakash

results.title: Shrine
results.creator_credit: Cambridge Film Productions, John Dixon, Film Victoria, Kent Chadwick and David Bilcock
results.brief_description: The Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne was built as a memorial to Victorians who served in the first World War, and also honours those who served in the Second World War. The film looks at the Shrine, and the feelings of pride and mateship amongst Australian soldiers who fought in both wars.

results.title: Shrek [DVD]
results.creator_credit: NBCUniversal, Aron Warner, John H. Williams, Jeffrey Katzenberg, Andrew Adamson and Vicky Jenson
results.brief_description: Once upon a time in a land far, far away, and so begins this animated fantasy. Set in a fantastical kingdom inhabited by fairy tale creatures, the story finds the enchanted princess, Fiona (Cameron Diaz) locked away in a tower guarded by a dragon; a scheming Lord Farquaard (John Lithgow) who wants to marry the princess so he can become King; an unlikely hero, the lovable ogre Shrek (Mike Myers) and his sidekick, Donkey (Eddie Murphy), who are sent by Farquaard to rescue the princess and bring her back to be his bride. Children will enjoy the tale for what it is - a lively romp, while adults will enjoy the many intertextual references to numerous other fairy tales.

results.title: Shred of evidence
results.brief_description: This program looks at the work done by the Forensic Science Laboratory in London which was founded in 1935. It’s aim is to outwit the criminal and provide evidence for the court. Some scenes may be upsetting to some people.

results.title: Showtime [b&w]
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and Anne Bourke
results.brief_description: A film of the Royal Melbourne show as seen through the eyes of a family group. Grandfather, a retired farmer, takes his daughter and her two teenage children to the show. To people like breeders of livestock, farmers and agricultural equipment salesmen, the show is an important yearly event, but for the family there is something to interest each member. Cooking demonstrations, displays of horsermanship, and the extensive pavilions showing domestic pets as well as farm animals all have their appeal.

results.title: Shows Promise: Should Go Far (Exceptional Children)
results.brief_description: A study of four exceptional children in one family, each excelling in at least one area of learning. Examines their upbringing and the key role played by their mother who has been influenced by Montessori.

results.title: Shows promise - should go far (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Yorkshire Harlech Television, Michael Deakin and Michael Tuchner
results.brief_description: A study of four exceptional children in one family. Each child excels in at least one area of learning, eg., mathematics, music, painting. The film looks at the children’s upbringing and its influence on their development. Their mother explains her situation and philosophy underlying her upbringing of the children.

results.title: Shown by request
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit, Alexander Shaw and Colin Dean
results.brief_description: Story of 16 mm film use and distribution in Great Britain. Films being used in village hall, in the country, during a factory lunch hour; how the film library works, the procedures in handling a new film and the method of handling requests through all steps until the film has been returned, repaired and put back in the vault.

results.title: Showgirls
results.creator_credit: Chargetex 6 S A, United Artists Corporation, Charles Evans, Alan Marshall and Paul Verhoeven
results.brief_description: Topping worst film of the year lists and castigated by critics as “distasteful”, “sleazy” and “high gloss trash”, Paul Verhoeven’s “Showgirls” is unashamedly trashy, completely unpretentious, genre fun. That it provoked such knee-jerk reactions only shows just how ahead of the game it is. With nothing to lose, the young, feisty Nomi Malone hitches a ride to Las Vegas to become a dancer. She starts off working at The Cheetah, a sleazy striptease, lap-dancing joint, before catching the attention of Cristal Connors, star of Las Vegas’ most upscale dancehall-casino. The sensuous, quasi-dominatrix, Cristal, is attracted to Nomi and impressed by her dancing skills. Eventually, Nomi is accepted into the exclusive dance show and is able to strut her stuff. We get to witness the level of bitchiness behind the stage in the dressing room where the fiercest is between Nomi and Cristal. This bitchiness, which borders on lust and attraction, intensifies when Nomi starts dating Zack Carey, Cristal’s current lover and the show’s Executive Director, who consequently promotes Nomi to the position of Cristal’s understudy. A la “All About Eve”, Nomi eventually gets her chance as the show’s lead and becomes the toast of town. It’s at the top, however, that Nomi witnesses firsthand the corruption and evil that runs riot in Las Vegas. Written by one of Hollywood’s highest paid screenwriters and regular Verhoeven collaborator, Joe Eszterhas, “Showgirls” is filled with lowly, tawdry behaviour, cliches and plot points: bitchiness, infantile power games, old-fashioned representations of gender and sex, naked ambition, sexist machismo, and even an odd value system which sees Nomi making claims to artistry and objecting to charges of being a whore whilst at the same time climbing the ladder via sleeping with her boss and giving audiences all the body they can muster. But like all good B-grade, exploitation cinema, Verhoeven indulges in genre cinema and lowly attitudes of sex and gender in a highly energised, dazzling mode in order to give them a new spin. Ultimately, “Showgirls” is an honest portrayal of the superficiality and tawdriness of Las Vegas, aka America. Stars Elizabeth Berkley, Kyle MacLachlan, Gina Gershon, Glenn Plummer.

results.title: Shower = Xizhao
results.creator_credit: Imar Film Co, Xi'an Film Studio, Peter Loehr and Yang Zhang
results.brief_description: This sentimental family drama/comedy from Yang Zhang is set amid the ritualistic world of the Chinese bathhouse and has as its central conflict, family tradition and difference between generations. Da Ming is a businessman, happily ensconced in city ways, who receives a cryptic card from his mentally-handicapped, but exuberant and eternally happy brother, Er Ming. Fearing the worst, Da returns home to find his father contentedly running the local bathhouse, in a decaying neighbourhood of Beijing, and also acting as marriage counsellor and mediator to the many petty quarrels that abound within the male dominated arena. Although urbanised, Da’s ties to the ways of his family and background are rekindled. The bathhouse is more or less a character in itself - it serves as a meeting place for men, especially the elderly, who engage in the bathing practices, including suction cups, massage and shaving, whilst discussing the minutiae of life, and blissfully engaging in ceremonies steeped in old world values, keeping the time-pressed pace of modernisation at bay. At times the tone of the film is cloying, but the overall impression is one of a lilting comedy that speaks of China’s contemporary cultural issues examined within the experience of one small family. In Mandarin with English subtitles.
